The National Research Council Canada (NRC) is in need of building condition assessments to evaluate the current condition of six of its real property assets.
">
The properties in need of assessment are: Buildings BOU-1, BOU-2, BOU-3, BOU-5, 75 boulevard de Mortagne, Boucherville, QC J4B 6Y4 ,";"; Buildings SAG-1, SAG-2, SAG-3, 501 boulevard de l'Universit est, Saguenay, QC G7H 8C3;
">
These assessments are part of Real Property Planning and Management’s (RPPM) on-going efforts to determine the most appropriate management strategy for the retention, maintenance and/or rehabilitation/renewal of the site, buildings and building elements in order to satisfy the Government of Canada’s (GoC) current and future requirements as they relate to their Science Assets.
">
Given the significant investment required to recapitalize these assets, the importance of a repeatable, rigorous, analysis of the inventory, including condition assessment, financial, utilization and adequacy, is critical to the ongoing life-cycle management of these assets. Building Condition Assessments provide foundational, detailed, technical information on which these analyses are based.
">
The Building Condition Assessment process is used to assess the physical condition of real property assets. The intent is to generate building condition information that enables capital planning for rehabilitation, renovation and replacement based on objectively applied criteria of condition.
">
For each building, the Building Condition Assessment must include the following information:
">
• General characteristics of a site, building and building elements
">
• History of additions, renovations or major system improvements
">
• Condition rating of building elements such as structure, building envelope, electrical, and mechanical systems
">
• Comments on maintenance requirements
">
• Comments on essential corrective/remedial requisites
">
• Information on the life-cycle capital cost of refurbishment or replacement of building elements
">
• Information on the current replacement value (CRV) or replacement cost new (RCN) of each building, including major group elements (ASTM Uniformat II Level 1), group elements (ASTM Uniformat II Level 2), individual elements (ASTM Uniformat II Level 3), and sub-elements (ASTM Uniformat II Level 4).
">
• Capital cost plans presented on a yearly basis for work over the next 25 year life-cycle of the buildings and elements
">
The concept of full life-cycle costing for a facility serves as the foundation for the development of a long-term capital plan. The 25-year capital plan should indicate the optimal timing/grouping of recommended ‘events’ into projects in order to minimize overall cost and building occupant disruption.
">
Estimated quantity of commodity: 6 Buildings for assessment
">
Duration of contract: 2023-02-15 to 2023-06-30
">
Time frame of delivery: 2023-02-15 to 2023-06-30

# Government Tender Announcement

[Published on December 14, 2022]

### Project Title
Regional Building Condition Assessment - Boucherville/Saguenay

### Project Reference Number
PW-22-01017286
### Tender Closing Date and Time
January 31, 2023, 2:00 PM ET

### Brief Overview

The National Research Council Canada (NRC) is soliciting proposals for a Building Condition Assessment (BCA) project in Boucherville and Saguenay, Quebec. The project aims to evaluate the physical condition of six NRC-owned properties, providing detailed technical information for capital planning and management.

### Project Details

The BCA will assess the condition of buildings BOU-1 to BOU-5 and SAG-1 to SAG-3, including their structure, building envelope, electrical, and mechanical systems. The assessment will also identify maintenance requirements, essential corrective/remedial needs, and capital costs for rehabilitation or replacement.

### Key Objectives

* Evaluate the physical condition of buildings and identify areas requiring attention.
* Assess the life cycle costs of building elements and provide recommendations for capital planning.
* Provide a detailed report outlining the condition of each building, including images and metrics.

### Proposal Requirements

* Proposals must include a detailed project plan, methodology, and timeline.
* Respondents must demonstrate experience in BCA projects, with a minimum of five years' experience in assessing similar building types.

### Evaluation Criteria

* Technical merit (40%): The proposal's technical approach, methodology, and experience.
* Quality of work (30%): The quality of the work scope, including documentation and deliverables.
* Responsiveness (20%): The responsiveness of the proposal to the project requirements and timelines.
* Cost and pricing (10%): The proposed cost and pricing, in accordance with the tender's financial requirements.

### Key Dates

* Tender closing date: January 31, 2023, 2:00 PM ET.
* Estimated contract duration: February 15, 2023, to June 30, 2023.

### Contact Information

Collin Long, (343) 549-1549, Collin.Long@nrc-cnrc.gc.ca
